title-group.article-title: First Bite Syndrome Following Ipsilateral Carotid Endarterectomy

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Vascular Surgery, Auckland City Hospital, Auckland, New Zealand

author-notes.corresp: Tom Kai Ming Wang, Department of Vascular Surgery, Auckland City Hospital, 2 Park Road, Grafton, Auckland 1023, New Zealand. Email: TWang@adhb.govt.nz

abstract.p: First bite syndrome (FBS) is characterized by unilateral pain in the parotid region after the first bite of each meal, usually following ipsilateral neck surgery. The proposed mechanism is sympathetic denervation of the parotid gland, from iatrogenic injury to the sympathetic trunk supplying this gland. Local botulinum toxin injection has emerged as a promising treatment option with favorable results. To date, there are 3 published cases in the literature describing FBS after carotid endarterectomy. We present a case of a 75-year-old gentleman who developed FBS after carotid endarterectomy, to raise the awareness of this unusual and uncommon complication.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The symptoms of first bite syndrome (FBS) were first described by Gardner et al in patients post superior cervical ganglionectomy in the 1950s as pain which occur with the first bite of food and after a matter of seconds disappears and usually does not return during the rest of the meal. 1 The condition was named by Haubrich in 1986. 2 Since then, many published articles have described patients with FBS following head and neck surgery, including cases involving resection of cervical schwannomas, 3
–6 vagal paragangliomas, 3
,7,8 carotid body tumors, 3
,6,9,10 parotid adenoma, 3
–6 pharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas, 11 metastatic papillary carcinoma, 6 and hypertrophic styloid process. 12 Three case reports also observed patients presenting with FBS not related to surgery and subsequently were diagnosed with parotid 13
,14 or neck 15 tumors. To date, there are only 3 published cases of FBS after carotid endarterectomy in the literature. 16 –18

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 75-year-old man presented with several self-resolving episodes of ataxic gait, slurred speech, and vague perioral paraesthesia lasting for a few minutes over a period of a few days. Relevant past medical history included peripheral vascular disease requiring right femoral-popliteal bypass in 2011, hypertension, and smoking. Following admission and review by the neurology team, he was diagnosed with vertebro-basiliar transient ischemic attack after computed tomography of the head revealed no significant abnormality. A carotid ultrasound was done as part of the investigations and showed an occluded left internal carotid artery (ICA), critical (80%-99%) right ICA stenosis, and bilateral patent vertebral arteries with antegrade flow. He was subsequently referred to vascular surgery outpatient clinic and underwent surgery for asymptomatic critical stenosis of the sole (right) ICA.

Right carotid endarterectomy was performed 2 months later under general anesthesia. An anterior sternomastoid incision was used and on dissection revealed a carotid artery bifurcation slightly higher than normal but readily accessible. The vagus and hypoglossal nerves were identified and isolated, the latter requiring mobilization to enable access to the undiseased segment of ICA above the plaque. The superior thyroid artery was ligated, and the external carotid artery (ECA) and mid-ICA clamped, followed by arteriotomy, revealing high-grade plaque with no features of acute plaque pathology in the proximal ICA. A Sundt shunt was inserted before routine endarterectomy was performed with eversion endarterectomy of the ECA. A bovine pericardial patch was used over the endarterectomy site, followed by shunt removal, declamping, hemostatic control, and wound closure. There was some suspicion as to iatrogenic clamp injury to the vagus nerve following reclamping after shunt removal and the clamp was repositioned immediately.

The patient awoke neurologically intact but had a hoarse voice, and laryngoscopy a few days later on the ward revealed right vocal cord paralysis. He was discharged on day 4 postoperation, and at the follow-up to clinic 1 month later, he still had a hoarse voice. It was during this follow-up visit that he complained of having severe pain in the right cheek with the first bite of a meal which subsequently resolves, but returns at the next meal. This started 2 weeks after the operation. He was seen by the otorhinolaryngology team the next week where he was still noted to have immobile right vocal cord on nasolaryngoscopy which medialized well following vocal fold injection laryngoplasty with Restylane. The voice immediately improved postprocedure. The diagnosis of FBS was then made by the otorhinolaryngoly team, and the right parotid gland was subsequently injected with botulinum toxin A injection (50 U in 1 mL) and at 1 month after injection there was some improvement in the pain symptoms.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
Clinically, FBS presents as ipsilateral parotid region cramping pain after neck surgery usually within 2 weeks, 1
,3 but sometimes several months later, 12,19 or even before surgical resection of neck tumor. 13 –15 Early studies linked the pathogenesis of FBS to deliberate or inadvertent resection of the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion following surgery of the parapharyngeal space. 1
,2 Netterville et al subsequently proposed that FBS is due to sympathetic denervation of the parotid gland, with subsequent hypersensitivity and supermaximal response to parasympathetic neurotransmitter release after oral intake, inducing spasm of myoepithelial cells and therefore pain. 7

Truax et al who presented the first FBS case following carotid endarterectomy case similarly proposed that this syndrome was due to sympathetic denervation, though they suggested the mechanism to be unopposed parasympathetic-mediated glandular vasodilation and vasoactive intestinal peptide release that causes the symptoms. 16 The sympathetic supply to the parotid gland originates from the anterior branches of the postganglionic nerves of the superior cervical ganglion, which then joins the external carotid plexus. 4 This suggests that surgery around the ECA during mobilization, isolation, and clamping can potentially cause FBS due to disruption of these sympathetic fibers, without causing Horner syndrome as sympathetic supply of the eye originates from the internal carotid plexus.

There is no current consensus on the optimal strategy for managing FBS. 4,8 Some groups have opted for conservative management as FBS is frequently self-limiting and resolves between 6 and 12 months; 17
,18 however, there remains a small percentage of patients who have persisting symptoms beyond this time. 1
,6 Strategies such as dietary modification, including eating bland food, have been suggested as a means to decrease the severity of symptoms by reducing salivation. 7 Gabapentin, carbamazepine, and/or amitriptyline have been tried with mixed results. 7
,8,12,17

More recently, botulinum toxin injection into the parotid gland has been reported to relieve FBS symptoms. In a case series of 5 patients who had FBS after neck surgery for tumors for 22 to 60 months, 3 doses of 11 U botulinum toxin A were injected into the parotid gland. 6 There was a statistically significant decrease in scores for parotid pain, troubles with enjoying meals, and interference with daily activities at 1 and 3 months postinjection from preinjection. The likely mechanism is through paralysis of the parasympathetic supply of the parotid gland to decrease the pain associated with salivation. Our patient also had botulinum toxin A parotid injection (50 U total), with partial improvement 1 month later.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The FBS appears to be an uncommon and underappreciated complication of the neck surgery. We present the fourth case of FBS after carotid endarterectomy secondary, most likely, to iatrogenic injury to the sympathetic plexus surrounding the ECA with a view to increase the awareness about this rare neuropathic syndrome condition following carotid surgery.
